This folio contains Harriot's proof of the angle preserving properties of stereographic projection. For the diagram see Add MS 6789, f. 18
For further details, including a transcript and translation, see Jon Pepper, 'Harriot's calculation of the meridional parts as logarithimic tangents', Archive for History of Exact Sciences, 4(1968), 359–413 (pages 366–367, and 411–413).

div.head:
Quod rumbus in planispærio nostro facit angulum cum meridiano
æqualem angulo facto a rumbo cum meridiano in sphæera.
That a rhumb in our planisphere makes an angle with the meridian equal to the angle made by the rhumb with the meridian on the sphere.

p.s:
Sit $ ABE $ semicirculus pro
meridiano quolibet in globo
terrestri.
Cuius centrum $ e $. poli $ A $ et $ E $.
In illo meridiano sumatur quoduis
punctum $ B $.
Sit, $ e X $, communis sectio plani
æquatoris et plani meridiani,
quæ meridianus est in nostro
planisphærio correlatiuus meridiano
in globo terrestri.
In semicirculo pro meridiano
sumatur quodvis punctum $ B $.
Agatur recta $ AB $ producta quæ
secabit, $ eX $, in puncto $ b $,
et punctum $ b $ in planisphærio erit
correllatium puncto $ B $ in superficie
sphæræ.
Agatur etiam recta, $ e B $, et $ GH $
tangens peripheriam in puncto, $ B $.
Dico primo quod anguli $ HBb $ et $ HbB $
sunt æquales.
$ HBb + ABe = $ recto.
$ ebA + eAB = $ recto.
Ergo: $ HBb + ABe = ebA + eAB $.
Sed: $ ABe = eAB $.
ergo: $ HBb = HbB $.
Let $ ABE $ be a semicircle on any meridian of the terrestrial sphere, with centre $ e $, and poles $ A $ and $ E $. Let $ eX $ be the intersection of the equator and the meridional plane, which meridian in our planisphere corresponds to the meridian in the terrestrial sphere.
In the semicircle take any point $ B $ on the meridian. Construct the extended line $ AB $ which will cut $ eX $ in the point $ b $, and the point $ b $ in the planisphere will correspond to the point $ B $ on the surface of the sphere. Also construct the lines $ eB $ and $ GH $ touching the circumference in the point $ B $.
I say first that the angles $ HBb $ amd $ HbB $ are equal.
$ HBb + ABe = $ a right angle.
$ ebA + eAB = $ a right angle.
Therefore $ HBb + ABe = ebA + eAB $.
But $ ABe = eAB $.
Therefore $ HBb = HbB $.

Iam intelligitur $ B $ punctum esse centrum
circuli nautici qui vulgo compassus
dicitur; sive circuli horizontis visibilis.
cuius plano $ eB $, est ad angulos rectos.
$ GH $ est communis sectio plani meridiani
et illius circuli nautici, et est linea dicta
meridiana in plano horizontis circuli nautici.
Agatur quælibet linea $ BD $ in plano horizontis faciens quemvis angulum $ DBG $
cum meridiana $ BG $
et in illa linea sumatur quodvis punctum $ D $
et Agatur $ DC $ perpendicularis ad $ GH $.
Conectantur puncta $ AC $: et $ AD $. et constituatur
pyramis cuius basis $ BCD $, et vertex, $ A $.
Quoniam $ CD $, perpendicularis est in plano
erecto ad planum meridionis circuli productum
erit etiam perpendicularis ad $ CA $, et planum
trianguli $ DCA $ erit erectum ad planum
meridiani.
Linea $ AC $, secat, $ e X $, in puncto $ c $
(non opus est ducere lineas
$ DF $, et $ CF $. ideo omittuntur).
Now it is to be understood that the point $ B $ is the centre of a nautical circle, which is commonly called the compass; or circle of the visible horizon, which is at right angles to the plane of $ eB $.
$ GH $ is common to the plane of the meridian and that nautical circle and is said to be the meridional line in the horizontal plane.
Construct any line $ BD $ in the horizontal plane making any angle $ DBG $ with the meridian $ BG $ and in that lane take any point $ D $, and construct $ DC $ perpendicular to $ GH $. Join the points $ AC $ and $ AD $ to make a pyramid whose base is $ BCD $ and vertex $ A $. Since $ CD $ is a perpendicular in a plane at right angles to the plane of the circle of the meridion, it is also perpendicular to $ CA $, and the plane of triangle $ DCA $ will be at right angles to the plane of the meridian.
The line $ AC $ cuts $ e X $ in the point $ c $.
(there is no need to draw the lines $ DF $ and $ CF $, therefore they are omitted).

And in the plane $ ACD $, there is constructed $ cd $ from point $ c $ at right angles to the line $ AC $, which will cut $ AD $ in the point $ d $. And it will be common to the equatorial plane and the triangle $ ACD $. Join the points $ d $ and $ b $.
I say that the angle $ dbc $ in the equatorial plane is equal to angle $ DBC $ in the horizontal plane, or nautical circle.
Let $ AB $ be extended, and let $ CF $ be perpendicular to it. Make $ FP = FB $ and construct $ FC $, $ FD $, $ PC $, and $ PD $.
Since $ DC $ is perpendicular to the plane of the meridian, it makes right angles with $ CA $, $ CB $, $ CF $, and $ CP $.
Since also $ CB $ and $ CP $ are equal, the right-angled triangles $ BCD $ and $ PCD $ are equal and equiangluar, and the angle $ CBD $ is equal to $ CPD $. But the angle $ cbd $ in the equatorial plane is equal to $ CPD $, because the triangles $ cbd $ et $ CPD $ are parallel, for $ cd $ is parallel to $ CD $, and so are $ cb $ and $ CP $ since
$ cbA = CPA = CBP = HBb = HbB $
Therefore the third side $ db $ is parallel to $ DP $, and so the planes of the triangles $ cbd $ and $ CPD $ are parallel. And similarly also angles $ cbd = CPD $.
Therefore $ cbd = CBD $, as was to be proved.
Another way, $ db $ is parallel to $ DP, since:

That a rhumb in our planisphere makes an angle with the meridian equal to the angle made by the rhumb with the meridian on the sphere.

Corollarium
Sequitur quod planisphærium non erit
solummodo planum æquatoris, sed quodlibet
planum illi parallelum, in quo omnia
erunt analoga.
Corollary.
It follows that the planisphere is not only the equatorial plane, but any plane parallel to it, in which everything is analagous.

The page is part of Harriot’s introduction of compound diagrams of motion, a group of folios on which Harriot eventually succeeds in deriving, by means of such diagrams, a general expression for the time of flight of a projectile (Schemmel 2008, Section 8.2).

The problem of finding the time of flight of a projectile formulated on the upper part of f. 26 is adequately reformulated in terms of a compound diagram of motion. The result is noted as an equation as well as a proportion.

The page is part of Harriot’s introduction of compound diagrams of motion, a group of folios on which Harriot eventually succeeds in deriving, by means of such diagrams, a general expression for the time of flight of a projectile (Schemmel 2008, Section 8.2).

On this page, Harriot first formulates the problem to find the range of a shot depending on the elevation angle and describes the first step to solve it, the determination of the time of flight of a projectile. The compound diagram of motion he puts forward (lower drawing on this page) is inadequate for solving this problem. The calculations based on this erroneous diagram are found on f. 25. The problem is adequately formulated and solved on f. H-23.

The page is part of Harriot’s introduction of compound diagrams of motion, a group of folios on which Harriot eventually succeeds in deriving, by means of such diagrams, a general expression for the time of flight of a projectile (Schemmel 2008, Section 8.2).
On the lower part of the page there is a graphite drawing of a projectile trajectory, similar to the upper drawing on f. 26.

div.head: 2.) For oblique motions.

p.s: Blank page
1.) For oblique motions.

This is the first of a sequence of paginated pages on which Harriot explores what may be called the inclined-plane conception of projectile motion, see (Schemmel 2008, Chapter 8). According to this conception, projectile motion is composed of a decelerated motion in the oblique direction of the shot, and an accelerated motion of vertical fall. The dependence of the oblique motion on the angle of projection corresponds to that of a motion along an inclined plane on the angle of inclination.

More specifically, the page is part of Harriot’s introduction of compound diagrams of motion, a group of folios on which Harriot eventually succeeds in deriving, by means of such diagrams, a general expression for the time of flight of a projectile (Schemmel 2008, Section 8.2).

On this particular page, Harriot demonstrates that the spaces traversed by two motions along planes of different inclination, ending at the same degree of velocity, as well as the times needed to traverse them, stand in inverse proportion to the degrees of the two motions taken at some arbitrary point in time.

The page is part of Harriot’s introduction of compound diagrams of motion, a group of folios on which Harriot eventually succeeds in deriving, by means of such diagrams, a general expression for the time of flight of a projectile (Schemmel 2008, Section 8.2).

Algebraic expressions are derived for the final degree of velocity of a downward motion (or, equally, for the first degree of an upward motion) along an inclined plane of equal length to a given vertical line, assuming the final degree of velocity of the motion of fall along the vertical and the inclination of the plane are given (Schemmel 2008, 307-8).

The ranges of Capo Bianco. pag. 34.
Experimented by a Sacre.
The page is part of Harriot’s notes on empirical ranges, see (Schemmel 2008, Section 8.4).
The notes on this page serve the comparison of Harriot’s theoretically calculated ranges to empirical ones extracted from (Capobionaco 1598, 34r, v).
He uses the values given for a saker with a cannon ball weighing 12 lb.
He scales the ranges several times and, in the table at the bottom of the page, also scales a part of them in such a way that they become comparable to his theoretically determined ranges.
In the crossed-out table in the middle of the page, elevation angles and ranges are incorrectly coordinated.

The page is part of Harriot’s calculation of ranges and his search for the projection angle of maximum range in the context of the inclined-plane conception of projectile motion, see (Schemmel 2008, Section 8.3).
Harriot derives a proportion for calculating ranges that does not involve the time of flight of a projectile.
The calculations on Add MS 6788, f. 158v suggested the proportion involving the time of flight to represent a detour.
As a matter of fact, however, using the new proportion the determination of ranges becomes more laborious.
Accordingly, on the following folios (Add MS 6788, f. 159v ff.) Harriot returns to the method used on Add MS 6788, f. 158v, see (Schemmel 2008, 312-3).

The reference to Bernardus Tornius Florentinus is to his commentary on De motu locali of William Heytesbury (c. 1313–1372/3). The text of Tornius is found as the seventh treatise in William Heytesbury, De sensu composito et diviso

(Thomas 1509) .

The texts of both Alvarus and Tornius are verbal, expressed in terms of repeated proportions. Harriot converts their results into arithmetic notation, and in doing so shows how to find sums of some infinite series that are not simple geometric progressions.
His first example (from Tornius) is $ \frac{2}{3} + \frac{4}{9} + \frac{6}{27} + \frac{8}{81} + \dots = \frac{3}{2} $. Harriot shows how this can be treated as the sum of infinitely many other series, each of which is a simple geometric progression, namely:
$ \frac{2}{3} + \frac{2}{9} + \frac{2}{27} + \frac{2}{81} + \dots = 1 $,
$ \frac{2}{9} + \frac{2}{27} + \frac{2}{81} + \dots = \frac{1}{3} $,
$ \frac{2}{27} + \frac{2}{81} + \dots = \frac{1}{9} $,
$ \dots $. The sums of these series form a new geometric progression $ 1 + \frac{1}{3} + \frac{1}{9} + \dots = 1\frac{1}{2} $.
The other two series on the page (from Alvarus) are summed in the same way.

This page is part of Harriot's
experiments on refractive colours. Summary of Harriot's analysis of colour experiments with glass and water-filled prisms. The large diagram shows the geometrical construction for the 58° glass prism, and throughout the pages on both the glass and the water prism, this construction and its associated lettering are implicit. Despite the depiction of the glass prism, Harriot's summary here includes the water prism (which Harriot, in his papers, always calls an "angle," that can be filled with various liquids). The pair of "cardinals" he discovers for each substance ("vitri cardinales" and "aquae cardinales") indicate, in effect, the range of refractive indices that direct light passing through these substances towards either the red or yellow.

This page is part of Harriot's
experiments on refractive colours. By a method of successive approximations, Harriot searches for the secondary cardinal for his glass prism, that is, the refractive index governing the secondary ray ($be$ in the diagram on
f. 184), which, according to Harriot's theory of colour, is responsible for the appearance of colours. (As usual, the sets of four numbers are solutions of proportions: the first is to the second as the third is to the fourth, and one element is unknown, in these examples the fourth.)

In particular, Harriot calculates $bc$, the distance between the apex of the prism $c$ and the point $b$ that the eye observes on the prism, as a proportion of the distance between the prism and the card, $bk$. As the measurements on f. 190 record, $bc = \frac{11}{18}$ inches, and $bk = 6$ feet. If the latter is taken as 10000000, then $bc = 84876.543$.

div.head:
C. De coloribus per prisma vitreum.
On colours through a glass prism.

This page is part of Harriot's
experiments on refractive colours. A summary of experimental apparatus and the raw observational data that Harriot obtained over four days in April, 1605, observing the coloured fringes on a card viewed through a glass triangular prism and a water-filled triangular prism. In the subsequent pages (now very disordered in the manuscript volume), Harriot will use the data recorded here to obtain a range of 'cardinal rays' for the two substances; or, in effect, a range of refractive indices responsible for the production of the spectrum of colours.

div.head: observations of colours. Aprill 8. 9. 10. 11.

bis observata: id est duobus diversis diebus. tribus. 4or.

p.s:
This page is part of Harriot's
experiments on refractive colours. Harriot has discovered (on
f. 194) that simple analogy to the glass prism does not provide an adequate secondary cardinal for the water prism, Harriot now applies the entire method of the glass prism workings using the data for the water prism, to calculate the secondary cardinal from scratch. As in that case (see
f. 187) Harriot tries several approximations, before hitting on a 'good cardinal'.

div.head:
De coloribus per angulum aqueum.
On colours through a water prism.

p.s:
1. ponamus, ut diximus, cardinalem secundarium 48° 20′
0° 15′ 48″ 15‴. debet esse 30′ fere.
Let us assume, as I said, that the secondary cardinal is 48° 20′.
0° 15′ 48″ 15‴. It ought to be nearly 30′.

2. faciamus igitur novum cardinalem secundarium.
And so let us make a new secondary cardinal.

3. faciamus alterum cardinalem meliorem per proportionem.
Examinatio cardinalis.
Consentit cum observatis.
Bonus igitur cardinalis.
Let us make, by means of proportion, another, better cardinal.
Examination of the cardinal.
It agrees with observations.
And so this cardinal is good.

This page is part of Harriot's
experiments on refractive colours. Having found the secondary, colour-producing cardinal ray for the glass prism, Harriot turns to the water-filled prism. He first explores the possibility that the ratio between the primary and secondary cardinals for the water prism is the same as the ratio between the primary and secondary cardinals in the glass prism. He finds that this does not in fact accord with observation. Thus he will follow the same procedure as in the glass prism to find the secondary cardinal.

div.head:
A. De coloribus per angulum aqueum.
On colours through a water prism.

p.s:
Ponamus primo: secundarium cardinalem aquae ad primarium
esse ut secundarius vitri ad primarium.
Let us first assume: that the ratio of the secondary cardinal of water to the primary is the same as the secondary primary of water to its primary.

illam rationem non probant observata.
The observations do not support that ratio.

Ponamus 2o cardinalem secundarium 48° 20′.
Sed precedit sic operatio per primarium ut in (D) vitri.
Let us assume that the secondary cardinal is 48° 20′. But the operation proceeds by means of the primary cardinal, as on page D of the glass prism.

This page is part of Harriot's
experiments on refractive colours. Summary of raw data and analyzed results from experiments on refractive colours seen through various transparent substances in a 60° prism. These experiments were performed slightly after his work with a glass and water-filled prism, and he says that they were set up in the same way as those earlier experiments. The summary values of primary and secondary cardinals were no doubt also calculated in the same way (though the calculation pages are now missing).

f. 190, the 58° glass prism he used for his first experiments was irregularly shaped, and the observations were 'not to be trusted'. Most likely this is the reason that he recalculated, over two pages, the colour-producing cardinals for a regularly-shaped, 60° glass prism, using the same method as in the earlier pages on prismatic colours.

p.s:
This page is part of Harriot's account of the
refractive properties of the triangular prism.

Here, Harriot sets out the basic relations that hold among the angles of incidence and refraction, simply by reasons of geometry (i.e., independently of how one calculates the amount of refraction). He will use these identities throughout his treatment both of the simple refraction of light through the prism, and his
experiments on refractive colours, also conducted using triangular media.

div.head:
Lemma. Propositio.
Lemma. Proposition

p.s:
Duae perpendiculares super
duae lineas inclinantes
faciunt angulum aequalem
angulo inclinantium
Two perpendicular lines constructed upon two intersecting lines make an angle to each other equal to the angle between the intersecting lines.

div.head: Per angulum/prisma vitreum Through a glass angle/prism

p.s:
Adfractivus et Abfractivus aerei sunt eiusdem amplitudinis
Adfractus et Abfractivus vitrei sunt etiam aequales amplitudine.
The adfractive and abfractive rays in air are of the same angular size.
The adfracted and abfractive rays in glass are also equal in angular size.
Here Harriot uses a variation of his usual terminology for the multiple angles of refraction through an interface and back out the other side. [Diagram here??]
$\theta_1$: adfractivus (or incidens); translated 'adfractive'.
$\theta_2$: adfractus; translated 'adfracted'.
$\theta_3$: [incidens] abfractivus; translated 'abfractive'.
$\theta_4$: abfractus; translated 'abfracted'.
Harriot states here, then, that $\theta_1 = \theta_4$, and $\theta_2 = \theta_3$ — which is not true in general, but he will explain further below the circumstance in which this will be true.

Dato igitur triangulo angulo (prismatis); dabitur talis incidens adfractivus aereus
qui faciet abfractum aereum sibi amplitudine æqualem.
And so, given the triangle angle (of the prism), just such an incident, adfractive ray in air will also be given, which will make the abfracted ray in air equal to it in angular size.

div.head:
De medio densiori interposito.
Concerning a denser interposed medium.

p.s:
In medio planorum parallelorum, angulus adfractus
et abfractivus sunt aequales.
In a medium [bounded by] plane parallel sides, the adfracted and abfractive angles are equal.
That is, the two angles within the glass are equal, or $\theta_2 = \theta_3$.

In medio planorum inclinantium, differentia vel summa angulorum
inclinationis, et adfracti, est amplitudo abfractivi.
In a medium [bounded by] inclined plane sides, the difference or sum of the angle of inclination and the adfracted angle, is the angular size of the abfractive ray.
That is, if the sides are inclined at some angle (say $C$), then $C \pm \theta_2 = \theta_3$.

div.head:
Angulus inclinationis
minor adfracto.
Angle of inclination less than the adfracted [angle].

p.s:
Summa. Si perpendiculares
secant se mutuo extra
angulum inclinationis.
A sum: if the perpendiculars cut each other beyond the angle of inclination.

vide exempla magis adcommoda.
See the more salient examples.
These more salient examples are found on
f. 216.

Differentia. Se perpendiculares
secant se intra
angulum inclinationis.
A difference: if the perpendiculars cut each other within the angle of inclination.

div.head:
aequalis adfracto
equal to the adfracted [angle].

p.s:
3 casus. secantes se in una
linearum continentium angulum inclinationis.
Third case. Cutting each other in a single one of the line containing the angle of inclination.

nota:
In medio rariori iidem canones
mutatis solum ad in ab & contra.
Note: In a rarer medium, the same rules [apply], just changing 'ad' to 'ab' and vice versa.
That is, swap 'abfractus' and 'adfractus', and 'abfractivus' and 'adfractivus', or $\theta_2$ and $\theta_4$, and $\theta_1$ and $\theta_3$; so that, for example, the rule for a medium with sides inclined at angle $C$ becomes $C \pm \theta_4 = \theta_1$.

This page is part of Harriot's account of the
refractive properties of the triangular prism.

This page is the final draft of Harriot's general statement on the problems that need to be solved for the phenomenon of refraction, and forms part of his treatment of plane refraction. The first draft (substantially different in places) is found at f. 284. For details of the relationship between the versions, see that page. As in the translation of the first draft, the translation here reflects Harriot's final version, after deletions and additions. The commentary, where needed, will call attention to specific changes.

div.head:
Problema Elementum universale problematicum de refractionibus radiorum
Universal problematic foundation concerning the refractions of rays

p.s:
Oculo et puncto visibili existentibus in duobus mediis homogeneis dyaphanis dyaphanis, per se homogeneis inter se specie differentibus, et una superficie plana vel circulari sphaerica coniunctis.
The eye and the visible point being in two transparent media, in themselves homogeneous, but between themselves differing in kind, and conjoined at a plane or spherical interface.
Harriot's changes between the earlier version, and the version he finally arrives at here, are intended to remove any ambiguity in the notion of 'differing transparency'. Each substance, in itself, must be of quite uniform transparency; but there should be two different substances.

Tum: Dato, positione, radio unico incidente cum suo radio refracto: cuiuslibet alterius incidentis suum radium refractum accurate secundum leges Geometricas positione designare.
Then, given (in position) a single incident ray together with its corresponding refracted ray, to specify, in position, the refracted ray corresponding to any other given incident ray, according to the laws of geometry.

Iisdem datis in numeris, videlicet unico angulo incidentiae et suo angulo refractionis; cuiuslibet alterius anguli incidentiae angulum refractionis etiam in numeris exhibere.
The same being given in numbers (that is, a single angle of incidence and its corresponding angle of refraction), to express, also in numbers, the angle of refraction corresponding to another angle of incidence.

Aliud: Ab oculo in uno radio illorum radiorum ad visibile in altero, data recta positione et magnitudine, punctum refractionis extremorum in communi superficie mediorum invenire.
Another: the line from the eye (on one of those rays) to the visible object (on another) being given in position and magnitude, to find the point of refraction on the common surface at the boundaries of the media.
The previous two paragraphs were identical to their versions in the first draft. In this paragraph, concerning the 'second problem' of refraction — 'Alhazen's problem' for refraction, or the caustic problem — Harriot tightens up the language a little. There is a straight line joining the eye and the object (that is what is 'given'), but Harriot clarifies that this is not the path of the light: the eye and the object are each at the end of separate light rays. The problem is to discover where those light rays meet, at the common interface betweem the media.

Aliud: Datis duobus mediis dyaphanis per se homogeneis, inter se specie differentibus, ac superficie plana vel sphaerica coniunctis; datis etiam duabus lineis rectis continentibus angulum cuius complementum ad duos angulos rectos non est maius maximo angulo refractionis: communem superficiem mediorum ad communem intersectionem datarum linearum ita geometrice apponere, ut oculus positus in una datarum, videat alteram in eadem rectitudine.
Another: Given two transparent media, in themselves homogeneous, but between themselves differing in kind, and conjoined at a plane or spherical interface; and given also two straight line containing an angle, the complement of which with respect to two right angles does not exceed the greatest angle of refraction, to place geometrically the common surface of the media at the common intersection of the two lines, such that the eye, placed on one of the given lines, will see the other, along the same straight line.
This problem (not found in the first draft) amounts to solving the problem of refraction 'in reverse'. Here, we are given a broken, refracted path, and we have to orient the refractive surface at the broken point in the path, so that it forms a genuine light path under refraction.

This page may be related to Harriot's exploration of the elliptical refractaria, as seen at f. 320. Its presence in a bundle dealing with refraction suggests a connection. Harriot asserts (correctly) here that if a circle is "stretched" in one direction only (thereby undergoing, in modern terms, an affine transformation), one obtains an ellipse. At the bottom of the page, he seems to be making notes towards a proof of this. Perhaps his inability to find a demonstration led to his lightly scoring out of this page.

Si quotlibet lineis ordinatim applicatis ad diametrum circuli, addes numero
et quantitate aequales similiter applicatas ad similes partes lineæ
maioris vel minoris data diametro circuli: termini illarum linearum
sunt in ellipsi.
If, to however many lines placed as ordinates on the diameter of a circle, you add lines equal in number and size, and similarly applied, to the similar parts of a line that is greater or less than than the given diameter of the circle, then the ends of those lines lie on an ellipse.

This page is the first draft of Harriot's general statement on the problems that need to be solved for the phenomenon of refraction, and forms part of his treatment of plane refraction. The final draft is found at f. 246. The current page, f. 284, is found in the midst of a large sequence of papers (264-303) which are all concerned with refraction at a plane or in a glass or water-filled sphere. The same sequence includes ff.
266 - 268 , which Harriot dated to July, 1601, and which are the very earliest dated papers in which Harriot used the sine law of refraction. It is unclear whether this sheet is related to those dated sheets; but, given its elementary character, it is plausible that it too represents Harriot's early thoughts on refraction (and, since one of the problems posed here is precisely to discover a mathematical relationship in refraction, it may even pre-date Harriot's discovery of the sine law).

The relationship between the two drafts is a little complicated. The multiple deletions and alterations on this page leave little doubt that this is the first version, from which the final version at f. 246 was copied. However, Harriot seems also to have copied changes he made in the final version back into this first draft. For example, the original title of this little essay, in the first draft, was Problemata de refractionibus. In the final draft, after several attempts and deletions, he settled on the title
Elementum universale problematicum de refractionibus radiorum , which he then wrote back into the first draft.
The translation given here is of the final intended version of the text. The commentary will note any significant changes made by the deletions or additions.

div.head:
Problemata de refractionibus Elementum universale problematicum de refractionibus radiorum
Problems about refraction Universal problematic foundation concerning the refractions of rays

p.s:
Dato radio Oculo et puncto visibili existentibus in duobus mediis diversis diversae diaphanitatis homogeneis diaphanis diversae specie differentibus: et superficie plana vel circula sphaerica coniunctis.
The eye and the visible point being in two homogeneous transparent media differing in kind, and conjoined at a plane or spherical interface.
This is the beginning of Harriot's list of 'data' — the 'givens' of the problem of refraction. He had obviously intended that this first item should be something given, as in the following cases, and started to write 'Given a ray'. He no doubt abandoned this approach when he realized first that the eye and the visible point (as well as the media) were prior to the ray; and that locating the correct ray was actually one of the problems associated with refraction, if one were only given the eye and the object, as the aliud elementum below will make clear. He also hesitated how to describe the two media involved in refraction. Initially, he specified two media of 'diverse transparency', but that perhaps suggested that there could be grades of transparency within a single medium. He then specified that each medium should be homogeneous, but of different transparency — but whether they are differing in transparency is the very thing refraction experiments determine. Thus he settled on two homogeneous transparent substances, that are simply different in kind.

Dato, positione, radio unico incidente cum suo radio refracto: cuiuslibet alterius incidentis suum radium refractum accurate secundum leges Geometricas positione designare.
Given (in position) a single incident ray together with its corresponding refracted ray, to specify, in position, the refracted ray corresponding to any other given incident ray, according to the laws of geometry.
That is, if we are given accurately one incident ray and its refracted ray, to use what we would call a 'law of refraction', such that one can construct geometrically the refracted ray for any other incident ray.

Iisdem datis in numeris, videlicet unico angulo incidentiae et suo angulo refractionis; cuiuslibet alterius anguli incidentiae radium refrac angulum refractionis etiam in numeris exhibere.
The same being given in numbers (that is, a single angle of incidence and its corresponding angle of refraction), to express, also in numbers, the angle of refraction corresponding to another angle of incidence.
As is typical of Harriot, he is interested not only in a geometrical relationship between angles of incidence and refraction, but also an arithmetical one, that will allow him to calculate actual numerical sizes of refracted angles corresponding to measured incident angles.

Aliud elementum: Ab oculo ad visibile, data recta positione et magnitudine, punctum refractionis invenire.
Another foundation: the line from the eye to the visible object being given in position and magnitude, to find the point of refraction.
Here, Harriot raises another problem which will need to be resolved as an elementary foundation for the theory of refraction. If we are simply given the eye and the object, at a certain orientation to each other and distance on either side of the interface, how do we find the point on the interface through which an incident ray from the object will, after refraction, reach the eye? Or, to look at the problem from the other direction, where on the surface does the eye have to look in order to see the object? This is a quite distinct problem from that of the law of refraction, in which an incident ray to a particular point on the surface is given, and one has to find the refracted ray. This problem (sometimes called the 'caustic problem') bears the same relation to refraction as 'Alhazen's problem' (also investigated by Harriot) bears to reflection, and Harriot will investigate in detail elsewhere in these papers. [DIAGRAM WOULD BE USEFUL HERE!!]

div.head:
Definitiones
Definitions
Note that this heading, and all that follows, is not found in the later version of the text. NEED DIAGRAMS HERE!!!!

p.s:
Circulum Regium appello principalem et primum circulum diagrammatis.
I call the first and principal circle of the diagram the regal circle.

Regia quae est linea est semidiameter illius circuli.
The regal line is the radius of that circle.

Cardinalis circulus est secundus, et minor in diaphano medio densiori, sed maior in rariori.
The second circle is the cardinal, and it is smaller in a denser transparent medium, but larger in a rarer one.
Note that Harriot talks loosely here about more and less 'dense' media, even though he usually careful to deny any relationship between the density and refractive properties of a transparent medium (as he does in note 1 at the bottom of this page)

Popularis linea est varia pro diversa positione regiae incidentis: sed semper est pars cardinalis in superficie refractiva.
The popular line varies according to the different position of the incident regal ray; but it is always the part of the cardinal on the refractive surface.

Regipopularis illa linea dicitur quando habetur in iisdem partibus ut Regia.
That popular line is called regipopular, when it is on the same side as the regal line.

Cardipopularis quando in iisdem partibus ut Cardinalis.
And cardipopular, when on the same side as the cardinal line.

div.head:
Consectarium
Corollary

p.s:
Radius perpendicularis perpendiculariter incidens in medio densiori contrahitur; in medio rariori elongatur.
A ray, perpendicularly incident on a denser medium, is contracted; on a rarer medium, is extended.
It is a 'corollary' of the definitions, insofar as it follows immediately from the arrangement of the circles in the refraction diagram.

div.head:
Nota
Note

p.s:
1: Si refractio fieret ex difficultate transitionis et debilitate radiorum; quare tum idem sit angulus refractionis ex radiis solis lucentis, et sole non lucente de radiis secundae lucis sive sit debilis vel fortis.
If refraction took place because of the difficulty of passage of the rays and their weakness: why then would there be the same angle of refraction from the rays of the sun when it is shining, and from the sun when it is not shining, by rays of secondary light, whether weak or strong ?
That is, if the important aspect of a refractive medium were that it impeded the passage of light through its density (as optical theorists, from Ptolemy to Kepler, had assumed), we would then expect to see different refractive properties in direct sunlight, and in diffused light on a cloudy day. The final note suggests another argument against this view.

2: Quare etiam minores sunt anguli refractionis ex ae aqua ad crystallum vel contra quam ex aere ad aquam, quum ex doctrina illa debilitatis maior esset refractio.
And also, why are the angles of refraction from water to crystal, or vice versa, smaller than those from air to water, when (according to the theory of weakness) the refraction ought to be larger?

This page is part of Harriot's treatment of special angles of refraction: rays that are interesting primarily because of their properties in a spherical refracting surface, but also happen to exhibit unusual characteristics at a plane interface. In these pages, Harriot uses the plane characteristics, along with simple geometry and algebra, to calculate the exact size of the angles of incidence. These pages all presuppose a sine law of refraction, expressed as constant "regial" and "cardinal" rays. The values of some of these rays, for different pairs of media, are recorded on Harriot's tables of refraction, starting at fol. 88.

div.head:
De refractionibus
Ab aere per sphæram crystallinam ad aerem
On refractions: from air, through a water sphere, to air

p.s:
Radius coincidens est ille qui refrangitur
ad terminum diametri.
The coincident ray is that which is refracted to the end of the diameter.

Vel: Est ille radius incidens aereus (ad planum
refractivum) qui productus abscindit
a perpendiculari imaginis, lineam æqualem
cardinali.
Or: It is that ray incident from the air (at a plane refractive surface) which, if produced, cuts from the line perpendicular to the image, a line equal to the cardinal [ray].
p.pc: Harriot characterizes this special ray in two different ways: first, as the ray refracted within a sphere to the very vertex of the sphere (depicted by him at fol. 104, where he also records the result calculated on this page); and secondly, as the ray refracted at a plane, such that the continuation of the ray cuts a length equal to the cardinal ray on the cathetus.

div.head:
1) Invenitur igitur ita
And so it is found this way

p.s: This page is part of Harriot's theory of refraction at a plane interface. It has been referred to several times in the literature on Harriot (for example, (Lohne 1959, 117), and especially (Lohne 1973, 203-4)).
Because of the tightness of the binding, there is probably some more text at the top of the page which is now illegible.

This is a new style of the "refractaria": the locus of an object's image under refraction. According to Lohne, Harriot developed this new style of diagram after he discovered the sine-law of refraction (that is, some time after 1601); in the light of more recent research on Snell's discovery of refraction (Hentschel 2001), it may be that Harriot, like Snell, actually used this diagram in order to discover the law itself. An example of a refractaria before his discovery of the sine-law is at fol. 411. There, the eye views different points on the surface of the water, and the apparent place of the floor of the vessel is marked; here, the eye views always the same place on the water (the center of the astrolabe), and the apparent place of the floor as seen through that spot is indicated.
The calculations at the bottom of the page use Harriot's sine law of refraction to calculate the angles in the diagram.

div.head:
Regium
Regal [circle]

p.pc: In the table, Harriot records his terminology for the four angles that light makes with a medium as it passes through an object such as a prism or a sphere (so, from air, to glass or water, to air, for instance, with two angles at each meeting with an interface). He first gives quite literal terms: The angle of incidence from air to water, and the refracted angle; the angle of incidence from water to air, and that refracted angle. But this terminology is wordy and potentially confusing: there are two angles of incidence, and two angles of refraction, which are only distinguished by writing out in full the pair of media and their order. Thus the "better names" for the four angles are: incidens (aereus) and adfractus; then, decidens (aqueus) and abfractus (modified slightly if the water and air are reversed). In the column of names below, Harriot appears to be experimenting with yet more elaborate schemes for naming the angles. In many of his pages on the transparent sphere and prism, he settled on the nomenclature adfractivus, adfractus; abfractivus, abfractus (some of which terms can be found on this page).

Angulus incidentiae
ab aere ad aquam

Angulus incidentiae
ab aqua ad aerem

p.s:
(Elipsis deformata)
Unlike the rest of the page, this phrase is written in Harriot's later hand (in which the letter "e" looks like a Greek ε). As will be seen below, the ellipse described here is indeed "deformed"

puncta 1, 2, 3, q, mechanicè
inveniebantur esse
in ellipsi.
quaere causam et
an sit universalis.
Points 1, 2, 3, and q were found mechanically to lie on an ellipse. Find out the reason, and whether it is universally true.
Harriot constructed four rays of incidence and their refractions. The incident rays were a vertical ray, a horizontal ray, and the rays sc and hc in his diagram, which are incident at angles of 30° and 60°, and are are refracted at 22° and 40° (as measured on the diagram, along rays cω and cψ). The vertical ray passes unrefracted, and the horizontal ray receives the maximum possible refraction in water, of 48° 30′. These refracted angles are very close both to the values Harriot tabulated in his post-sine-law refraction tables (fol. 89) and the historical values of Ptolemy and Witelo. Harriot's diagram is drawn accurately to within half a degree, so that he can examine "mechanically" the curve through the places of their images, 1, 2, 3, and q. Although Harriot recognizes that the line through these accurately plotted points appears to be an ellipse, neither of the two ellipses he actually describes here go through all four points. Perhaps that is why he noted, later, on the sheet that the ellipse (here depicted) was "deformed".

Est ut apparet in aliis chartis.
It is [universally true], as appears on other sheets.
Written subsequently, in different ink. On this sheet, Harriot suspects (correctly) that the floor of the vessel will appear to be an ellipse. He proves this to be the case in "other sheets," including
MS Add. 6787, fol. 535 .

lineam cq vel co
in multis
locis appellavi cardinalem.
potest etiam recte dici contracta,
et quando in medio rariori,
extensa.
In many places, I have called the line cq or co the "cardinal" line. It might just as correctly be called the "contracted line", or the "extended line", when it is in a rarer medium.
One of the puzzles of pre-Keplerian optics was the location of the image when a refracted object was viewed from directly overhead. Harriot places the object onto the inner circle of his double-circle construction for refraction.
This page is part of Harriot's treatment of burning mirrors, specifically, the concave spherical mirror.

This page contains Harriot's "Canonic" of the concave spherical mirror, identifying the principal rays that he will consider in almost all the papers that treat this mirror: the central ray (drawn in black in his diagram) incident on the mirror from the centre of the sun, and the proximate (yellow) and remote (red) rays, incident from opposite ends of a diameter of the sun; in other words, Harriot is interested in an ideal model of the extended sunbeam, rather than single parallel rays, thereby departing from the practice of all preceding opticians . The diagram gives the impression that the two extreme rays are obtained by rotating the central ray around the center of the mirror. That is, in fact, the construction implied in all of the spherical mirror pages.

div.head:
Canonicum ad sphæram concavam
Canonic for concave sphere

p.s:
Rubea
remotus.
Red, remote.
This page is part of Harriot's treatment of burning mirrors, specifically, the concave spherical mirror.

A ray incident parallel to the axis of a spherical mirror does not pass through the mirror's "focus" (located on the axis halfway between the surface of the mirror and the mirror's center of curvature); as the angle of incidence approaches 0°, the reflected ray cuts the axis between surface of the mirror and the focus, at a point ever closer to the focus. On the other hand, the extreme rays (the remote and proximate rays, as depicted in the
canonicum of the spherical mirror) behave quite differently from the central ray, at small angles of incidence. The remote ray, considered on this page, approaches a point distinct from the focus, and then rapidly diverges from it, back towards the surface of the mirror. That turning point in the distance between the focus and the axis intercept of the remote ray — the closest the remote ray comes to the focus — is what Harriot here calls the "radius tropicus." This point seems to be of interest to him, because it is the place at which the reflected ray is most concentrated on the axis, and thus where the mirror might be expected to produce maximum heat. Harriot discovers this point by trial and error (the trials beginning on the verso of this sheet).

Minima.
Punctus tropicus.
Minimum. Turning point
Harriot calculates the distance (call it $x$) between the center of the mirror and axis intercept of the remote ray corresponding to the central ray with an angle of incidence $\theta$, essentially using the formula $x = \frac{\sin\theta}{\sin(2\theta - 16′)}$. By testing values (tabulated on both sides of this sheet), Harriot finds here a minimum for $x$ of .5132268 which corresponds to $\theta = 7° 41′$

div.head:
In puncto concursus:
At the point of interception:

p.s:
Radius:
Remot.
Central.
Prox.
Ray: Remote, Central, Proximate
Harriot tabulates the angle at which each determining ray of the reflected sunbeam reaches the axis. This allows him to calculate the diameter of the cone of radiation that reaches the turning point, and thereby the burning power (tot soles), CONTINUE!!!!!!
This page is part of Harriot's treatment of burning mirrors, specifically, the concave spherical mirror.
Calculation of place where a ray of light, incident parallel to the axis of a spherical mirror, cuts the axis after reflection.

Harriot's source is almost certainly (della Porta 1593, 40-41), where della Porta proved that ray $EF$ (in Harriot's diagram) is reflected to point $G$, and $G$ is found at the interception of the perpendicular bisector $IG$ to the radius of the mirror $CF$, and the axis.

Harriot follows della Porta's construction precisely in the first part of this sheet, omitting della Porta's geometrical proof; but he adds (after the heading "Aliter") a trigonometrical version of the construction, which he will use as a means of calculation throughout the pages on the spherical mirror.

div.head:
De inveniendo puncto unionis coitionis concursus
radiorum solis, in concavo
sphærico.
On finding the point of union [meeting/interception] of the rays of the sun, in a concave spherical mirror.

[In cipher:] An yris videtur
in puncto yoonyonis.
No.
Is a rainbow seen at the point of union? No

p.s:
Sit radius solis $EF$ parallelus radio $CD$ transienti per centrum.
Let the ray of the sun $EF$ be parallel to the ray $CD$ passing through the centre.

Sit $FG$ radius
reflexus.
Let $FG$ be the reflected ray.

Queritur punctum $G$.
Point $G$ is sought.

Hoc est, longitudo lineæ $CG$.
That is, the length of the line $CG$.

Dividatur $CF$ bifariam in $I$.
Let $CF$ be bisected at $I$.

Fiat perpendicularis a puncto $I$ versus
partes $CD$.
Let a perpendicular be drawn from point $I$, in the direction of $CD$.

Et secabit $CD$ in puncto $G$.
And it will cut $CD$ at point $G$.

div.head:
Aliter.
Another way

p.s:
Ad lineam $FC$ et a puncto $F$ ducatur perpendicularis versus partes $CD$.
From point $F$, let there be drawn a perpendicular to line $FC$, in the direction of $CD$.

punctum concursus productæ $CD$ et perpendicularis erit punctum $H$.
The point of intersection of the perpendicular, and of the extended line $CD$, will be point $H$.

Linea $CH$ est secans anguli $FCH$.
Line $CH$ is the secant of the angle $FCH$.

Dividatur bifariam $CH$ et punctum
in medio erit $G$, punctum quæsitum.
Let $CH$ be bisected, and the point in the middle will be $G$, the sought point.

Vel $CG$ est dimidium secantis anguli $FCG$ vel $CFG$.
Or, $CG$ is half the secant of angle $FCG$ or $CFG$.
That is, the distance of the point of interception $CG$ from the centre is $\frac{1}{2}\sec\theta$, where $\theta$ is the angle of incidence of the ray.

Demonstratio est satis perspicua ex diagrammate.
The proof is clear enough from the diagram.

div.head:
Nota
Note

p.s:
$K$ est punctum medium inter $C$ et $D$.
$K$ is the midpoint between $C$ and $D$.

punctum $G$, nullius reflectionis erit inter $K$ et $C$.
Of no reflection will point $G$ be between $K$ and $C$.
That is, (as della Porta had shown), all rays are reflected between $K$ and $D$, with $K$, the midpoint of the axis, being the "burning point" of the spherical mirror (insofar as it has one at all).
This page is blank, except for a sketched diagram at the bottom.
The diagram illustrates reflections in a concave spherical mirror; the particular angles of incidence may be chosen to match those that della Porta considered in (della Porta 1593, 36-39).

The text referred to here is Alessandro Piccolomini's edition of the commentaries of Alexander of Aphrodisas on Aristotle's Meteorology.
(Piccolomini 1548) At the end of the book Piccolomino added the treatise De iride. Harriot's sketch looks like the beginning of Piccolomino's diagram on page 53v. Also mentioned is Joannes Grammaticus, or Joannis Philoponus, another commentator on Aristotle.

Alexander Piccolominis ad translationem suam comentarium Alex. Aphrodisæi
in lib. 4. Meteor. Aristotleles addidit tractatum de iride.

Alexandri Aphrodisæi comentarium Meteor. una cum opusculo de mixtione.
Alessandro Piccolomino added to his translation of the commentaries of Alexander Aphrodisias

This is part of a bundle concerning Harriot's refraction experiments of August 1597. This page, with its large heading, was perhaps meant to be the cover of the bundle. Harriot has listed (partly in cipher) the materials used in his experiments: a graduated staff, wax (to mark the point of refraction), a basin, and a ring (to mark the place of the image). Fuller details are given in the commentaries to other pages in this bundle.

As by experience I have found your singular humainty, by
late conferences, to make good the noble fame of your great learning
so hath itt emboldened me by thro my Lord to request that
you would send me word by this bearer the variation of
the nedle is about Mosco: for at this present I have such
an ympediment fallen into my toes that that I cannot walke
abroade otherwise I had been the presenter of this my
request unto you my selfe. which if it might have been
should then have moved some other questions viz whether it
is probable that the variation ran so in any plane of the world
180 degrees, or the north point of the needle stand directly to the south.
Allso whether a shippe sailing right east, or west by the compasse keepes upon
a parallell, as the common derived opinion amongst Maryners is, which
I think not because the east and west of the sonne also is a
Tangent to the parallell, but how little soever it so continues in
sailing, it is a portion or of the great circle of the east
and west, and therefore (I conceive) that cannot but decline from the
parallell. But ceasing to trouble you with these manner of
questions, I crave pardon for this my boldnes beseeching

Att your command
Jo: Rudston

This letter from William Lower to Harriot contains Lower's excited reactions to Galileo's Siderius nuncius (1610). He also refers to Kepler's De stella nova (1606).
He repeats requests for help with questions on Kepler and Viète. Such questions were posed in the letter in Add MS 6789, f. 437 to 428v, suggesting that this letter is the immediate successor to that one.

I gave your letter a double welcome, both be-
cause it came from you and contained newes of
that strange malaze; althoug that which I craved,
you have deferred till another time. me thinkes
my Diligent Galileas hath done more in his three-
fold discourse then Magellane in opening the straights
to the South sea or the Dutch that weare eaten
by beares in nova Zimbla. I am sure with more
ease & saftie to him selfe & more pleasure to me.
I am so affected with this newes as I wish som-
mer were past that I might observe this pheno-
menes also. in the moone I had formerlie observed
a strange spotednesse al over, but had no conceite
that anie parte therof mighte be shadowes; since I
had observed those degrees in the darker partes, of which
the lighter sorte had some resemblance of shadinesse
but that they grow shorter or longer I cannot yet
. there are three starres in orion below the
three on his girdle so much together as they appeared
about, 4. yeares since I was a writing you newes
out of Cornwall of a of a strange phenomenon
but asking some that had better eyes then myself
they told me, they were three starres lying close
together in a right line. thes starres with my
Cylinder this last winter I often observed, and it
was longe er I beleved that I saw them, they
appearinge through the Cylinder so farre & dis-
tinctlie asunder that without I can not yet dis-
sern. the discourse of this made me then observe
the, 7. starres also in, 8. which before I always ra-
ther beleved to be, 7. then such could nomber
them. thorugh my Cylinder I saw thes also plaine
lie and farre asunder, and more then, 7. to, but be-
cause I was preiudge with that number, I beleved
not myne eyes nor was carefull to observe how
manie; the next winter now that you have opened
mine eyes you shall heare much from me of this ar-

gument. of the third and greatest (that I confese pleased me
most) I have least to say; saving that iust at the instante
But I receaved your letters wee Philosophers
were a consideringe of Keplers * * pag: 106 de nova stella serpentarij reasons by which he indeavours to
overthrow Nolanus and Gilberts opinions concerning the immensitie
of the sphere of the starres and that opinion particularlie of
Nolanus by which he affirmed that the eye beinge placed in
mid popint of the univers the appearances would be still
one as with us here. When I was a sayinge that al-
though Kepler had sayd somethinge to most that might be
urged for that opinion of Nolanus yet or our principall thinge he
had not thought; for although it may be true that to the ey
placed in mid starre of, Cancer, the starres in Capricorne
will vanish, yet yet he hath not therefore so soundlie conlcuded
(as he thinkes) that threfore towards that part of the world
ther wilbe a voidnesse or thin scattering of little starres
wheras els round about ther will appeare huge starres close
thruste together: for sayd I (havinge heard you say often
as much) what if in that huge space betweene the starres
and Saturne, that remaine ever fixed, infinite numbers
which by reason of ther lesser magnitudes doe flee our sight
which may supplie the appearance to the eye that shall be placed in Cancer
what if about, Saturn. Jupiter. Mars. etc.
ther move other planets also
which appeare not. iust as I was a saying this comes
your letter. which when I had redd, loe, quoth I, what I spoke
probablie experience hath made good; so that we both
with wonder and delight fell a considering your letter.
we are here so on fire with thes things that I must send
my request and your promise to send mee of all sortes
of those Cylinders. my man shal deliver you monie for
anie charge requisite, and contente your man for his
paines & skill. send me so manie as you thinke need
full unto thes observations. send me also one of Galileus
bookes if any yet be come over and you can get them.
Concerning any doubte in Kepler, you see what it is to be
so far from you. what troubled me a month you satisfied in
a minute. I have supplied verie fitlie any wante
of a spheare, in the desolation of a hoghead, for the
hopes therof have framed one and a verie fine one.

I pray also of your leasure answer the other points
of my last letter concerning Vieta Kepler & your selfe.
I have nothing to presente you in counter, but gra-
titude with a will in act to be usefull unto you and
a power in proxima potentia; which I will not leave
also till I have beoughte ad actum. if you in the meane
time can further it, tell wher in I may doe you
service, and see how wholie you shall dispose of me.

Your most assured and loving
friend William Lower

Tra'venti the
longest day
of, 1610.

To his especial good
friend Mr Thomas Harriot
of Syon neere London.

Unfortunately, the opening of this letter is now lost.
In it, Lower requests help with his reading of Kepler.
He also asks for help with understanding some problems from Viète. He has evidently already received some notes from Harriot on one or both of the Appendices to Viète's Apollonius Gallus (1600); see Add MS 6785, f. 64, f. 64v, f. 355, and Add MS 6784, f. 331. Here Lower asks in particular about Problem V from Appendix II:

quote.s: Dato triangulo, invenire punctum, a quo ad apices dati trianguli actae tres lineae rectae imperatam teneant rationem.
Given a triangle, to find a point from which there may be drawn three straight lines to the apices of the given triangle, keeping a fixed ratio.

p.s:
& in mars is too longe & in some of the other
planets may be longe againe so in thos commets that
did appeare fixed the ellipsis may be neere a right line.

3. his phansie of ecliptica media or his via regia of the
sun. such the walke of al the other planets is obliq
more or lesse; each ther ecliptica vera under which the
earth walkes his ; by which he solves
handsomelie the of the starres latitudes.
Indeed I am much delighted with his booke but he is
so tough in manie places as I cannot bite him. I
pray write me some instructions in your next,
how I may deale with him to once master him
for I am readie to take paines. te modo jura
dantem indigeo, dictatorem exposco.
But on his booke I am much out of love with thes
particulars. 1. his manie and intollerable
atechnics. whence derive thos manie & uncertaine as-
sayes of calculation. 2. his finding fault with
Vieta for mending the like things in Ptol: Cop: etc.
but se the iustice Vieta speakes slightlie of Co-
pernicus a greater then Atlas. Kepler speakes as
slightlie of Vieta, a greater then Appollonius whom
Kepler much admires. for whosoever can
doe thos things that Kepler cannot doe, shalbe
to him great Appollonius. but enough of Kepler
let me once againe entreate your counsel how
to read him with best profit, for I am wholie
possessed with Astronomical speculations & desires.
for your declaration of Vieta's appendicle it is so
full and plaine as you have aboundantlie satisfyed
my desire. for such I yield you the thankes
I ought. onlie in a worde tell me whether by it
he can solve Copernicus, 5 cap: of his 5 booke.

the last of Vieta's problemes you have to speake
of because (you say) I had a letter of you, which was
more universal and more easilie demonstrated, and fi-
deth the point, $ E $. as wel out of the plaine of the tri-
angle given, as in the plaine. I pray here holpe
my memorie or understandinge, for although I have
bethought my selfe usque ad insania; I cannot admember
or conceave what proposition you meane. if I have
had such a one of you, tel me what one it is and by
what tokens I may know it. for you know how much I love
your things and of all ways of teaching for richnesse
& fullnesse for stuffe & forme, yours unto me are
incomparablie most satisfactorie. if your leasure give
you time importe also unto me somewhat els of your
riches in this argument.

Let me intreate you advise & direct this bearer
Mr Vaughan wher and how to provide himselfe of a
fit sphere; that by the contemplation of that our
imaginations here may be extended in manie spe-
culations that perplexe our understandings with dia-
grammes in plano. He hath monie to provide doe
you but tell him wher they are to be had and what
manner of sphere (I meane with what & how many
circles) wilbe most usefull for us to thes studies.
after all this I must needs tell you my sorrowes. god
that gave him, hath taken from me my onlie sun, by con-
tinual & strange fits of epylepsie or Apolepsie, when
in appearance, as he was most pleasant & good, he was most
healthie. but amongst other things, I have learnt of you to
setle & submit my desires to the will of god; onlie my
wife with more greife beares this affliction, yet now againe
she begins to be comforted. let me heare from you

and according to you leasure & friendshippe have di-
rections in the course of studies I am in. above al
things take care of your health. keepe correspon-
dence with Kepler. & whereinsoever you can have
use of me, require it with all libertie. soe I sign
ever

your assured & true friend to be
used in all things that you please
Willm Lower

Tra'venti on Mount Martin
6. february. 1610

To his especiall good
friend Mr Tho: Harryot
at Sion neere London.

Receaved by Mr
Phillip Vahan within
the myle of S.W.L.
at Mr
March. 10.
To be enquired of Mr Hall
where he lyes.
The book discussed on the first page of this letter was the Trigonometria of Bartholomaeus Pitiscus.

Sr I never loved huntinge till you furnished mee
with dogs. I will henceforward prove myself another
inded I soughte both arkes and tangents in the tables by pro-
portion onlie. so in a worde you have made me see
my faulte. or, 2. or, 3. more you have taught me to
amende it. onlie your sure dog Pitiscus will not
come into my sighte: but after a weekes vaine anger
and paines in seeking for him I found at last it
was not the poor Currs faulte but Mr Bills that
sending me the * * printed, 1608 second edition of the Trigonometria
sent me onlie the tables; so as turning the pages
75. 76. 78. 79. of the * * printed, 1600 first edition which is all I have
I found no such thinge as you cited nor no such
examples as you added. This is not the first time that
Bill hath sent me imperfect copies. I pray let him
understand so much. so, you see I am defeated of the
Curre dog; such indeed is not enough to give me satisfaction saving what I pick out of your letter.
let Kitt: when he goes next to London speake to
Bill or at the Blackfriers for a perfect copy of Pitiscus.
my brother the capitaine will sende it to mee speedilie.

the touch that you give of your doctrine of
differences of differences or triangular nombers en-
amours me of them. wherein to understand somethinge
I will one day be a beggar unto you.

Your dog that hunts by the sines onlie and I, am

your shee bitch hath no fellow for , onlie
she is slow. I had not lost hir, but knew hir

I need not be so curious to send you my doubts in

my worke is crowned now you allow of it and indeed

you have recomforted mee much to intimate that greate

Concerning the Joveall starres I wilbe workinge of

of thes things and thos other mirabilia quæ indices

my wiffe is well, now you know all my comfortes. I have

Your faithfull friend

Tra'venti

by the helpe of your dogs, I will renew all those workes

As in his letter of 6 February 1610, Lower is again concerned with problem 5 from Appendix II of Viète's Apollonius Gallus.

I so overwhelmed you the last time with a longe
letter, as it is iust I should make you amends
now with one as shorte. to send you none att all
(which perchance had been lost consideringe the use you
have of all your time) I could not consent unto,
out of the addiction and delighte I have to be still con
versinge with you. therfore I will onlie signifie
how it is with us and so an end. my course of cal-
culation I have stopte untill I heare from you; the two
greate causes of my stay I declared in my last let
ters. I fell since into Vieta's last probleme of his
second apendicle Apol: Gal: and compared his way with
yours that you last gave me: but to confesse a
truth I can have my will of neither; and the
probleme appeares to me not universall but requires
determination. for let the, $ ba $ given, have the same
sides, $ ab $. $ ac $. that Vieta's hath and lett, $ v' $, $ s'' $. be the
same that Vieta gives; now I will give a, $ \Delta $
that shall have thos sides, so it shalbe impossible
to finde anie pointe, from whence lines drawen unto
the corners be in the given rate. and that is by
givein a, $ \Delta $. with the same sides $ ab $. $ ac $. but onlie such a
position as the angle $ bac $ be $ > $ or $ < $ then Vieta's angle $ bac $. in such measure
as Vieta's two circles doe neither cut nor touch. this
rubbe put me out of this course. whereuppon I betooke
me to your problemes for the distinguishinge of the sides
of $ \Delta $les whether the summe or difference of the sides
and the angle adjacente or contained with the other
side were given. in this I proceed still with much
pleasure and satisfaction. I have also putt in order
all thos propositions which you also gave me, but I
had copied in lose papers & with ill diagrammes
so that all those thinges stand well and so I thanke god
doe we also. Excepte my catle which have all this
winter been persecuted wiht the Murraine. since
Christmas verie neare I have lost, 100. beasts; Vieta's
sacrifice to the witch Melusina for the invention of our probleme. but
I scarce keepe my promise with you. farewell.
I am all yours. Willm. Lower.

Tra'venti; 3.
April. 1611.

To his special good
friend Mr Thomas
Harriott. dd. this.

Since you incourage me so much I will proceded in
thos calculations of, Mars. and as I finish anie I will
send them unto you. indeed to find the issue so
and in the later so impossible to be re-
conciled had utterlie discouraged me, but that
now by your letter I perceave ther may bee good
use made such of ther discordance; therfore of
this I will say no more till I send you more.
the leasure that the countrie life affordeth us here
hath given me meanes to run over manie things
since I left the course of calculation; but amongst
others the, 3. vexations of scientificall mortals hath
held me most to wit the squaringe of the circle the
dubblinge of the Cube and the Philosophers stone. from the
two first I am come of handsomelie enough and
have made my selfe much sporte in the discove-
rie of mine owne parallogismes. but in the later
I sticke still and am like to make you sporte
ere I come fairelie of. but indeed I have here
much otime and therfore I may cast awaye some
of it in vaine pursuites. chusynge alwayes ra-
ther to doe somethinge worth nothinge then no-
thinge att all. How farre I had proceeded in
this, I ment now to have given you an account,
but that the report of the unfortunate erles re-
lapse into calamitie make me beleve that
you are enough troubled both with his misfortuntes
and my La: troubles; and so a discourse of this
nature would be unseasonable. neverthelesse
give me leave to crave a worde or two in
answere of thes doubts which I will breifelie pro
pound as followeth

1. first whether, sun. and, moon. bodies so difficulte
be dissolved as alchimists affirme. I meane
by dissolution(as I thinke they doe) that they meane must
bee putrified and distilled.

2. if they may be dissolved, whether with one simple
alone or with manie.

3. if they may bee dissolved and putrifyed. whe-
ther ther rectifyed partes beinge conjoyned a-
gaine wilbe multiplied in virtue.

4. and lastlie that which should have bene asked
first, an sit Elixir.

but at this time this much is to much. I am
sorrie to heare of the new troubles that and
pray for a good issue of them especiallie for
my La: sake and hir five litle ones. so for
the presente I rest as of old
your true friend
Willm Lower

Tra'venti, 19.
July. friday.
1611

To his especiall good
freind Mr Thomas Har-
riott att Sion.

Mr Harriot, when you were last in tonne you gave me thes two
followinge comparisons

which have assisted mee powerfullie in all Cubicke æquations, both to know
how manie and what the rootes are.

evre sine I left you, I have bine puslelinge to resolve that biqua-
drate æquation of the intercepted line I was in hand withall at Sion
wich drawe mee into the speculation of all biquadrate æquations, whence I
have spent all my time all my paper and all my witt and in
vaine. itaque for opem obsecro.

doe but send mee some shorte instructions (such as above which you
gave me once for Cubicks) to signifie unto mee what comparisons
ther are betweene the partes of biquadrate æquations, when the
rootes are one, two, three, or four, æquall or unæquall. and then
leave mee to pusle anon. if you helpe mee not my three
months speculation, will perish lamentablie.
your sure friend Willm Lower

To his verie lovinge friend
Mr Thomas Harriott att Sion

The one window is 8.foote $ \frac{6}{7} $ glass
The leade
withe the bands
lead for glass

stil I find that your counsel is alwayes to be followed
for havinge plaied seaveanighte I easilie found
out the equation, which before (darante tetelinge) I
could never doe

I am so fresh now as mee thinkes I can find out anie
thinge. I am much in love withe the reason of con-
struction of your table of proportionals; if when I
come next unto you, you would be pleased to make
me understand it, I shoulde be much beholdinge unto
you.

Yours in all thinges that he is able
Willm Lower
12th day.

To his verie deare
friend Mr Thomas
Harriot. Sion.

Good Mr Hariotts. Bycause I have noe other
newes to send you, you shall only recealv the bare relacion
of our voyage from Chatham to Margatt att the North-
forland. Which I can tell you in breiffe, though it was to us
(new seamen) very tedious. for wee went on baord the
sixt of Apr. and have but now arrived att the forland
the. 15. which you will say is very longe; but that you know
the danger of the sands, and contrarie windes too, if those
att Sion agree with those att sea. I have laerned here
certaine strange words amonge the Mariners, which to
interpret will require some tyme. If wee had bene
att Slushinge I mought perhaps have told you
now, but I could forebeare writinge to you noe
longer, though to little purpose, savinge only to
lett lett you understand, that wheresoever I am, I am
bound to remember you, and god rest

your very loyteringe but
lovinge shollar
Thomas Aylesburie

Margatt. 15. April.
1613.

I must not forget to tell you, your
glasses have fitted my lo. excellentlie well;
and so, as I feare you will loose them
both; but not without your own consent, which I
hope is have noe auctoritie to promise till wee
you give leave.

To my assured good
freind Mr Thomas
Hariots at Sion

Rec. Aprill.
24. th

Three reasons to prove that there
is a passage from the Northwest
into the South sea.

1. The tydes in Port Nelson (where Sr Tho: Button did
winter) move constantly. 15, or. 18. foote; which is not
found in any Bays Throughout the world but
in such seas as lie open att both ends to the mayne
Ocean.

2. Every strong westerne winde did bring into the
Harbor where he wintered, so much water, that the
Neap-tydes were æquall to the Spring-tydes,
notwithstanding that the Harbor was open only to the E. N. E.

3. In coming out of the harbor, shaping his course,
directly North, about, 60, degrees, he found a
strong race of a tyde, setting due East & West,
which in probabilitie could be noe other thing, than the
tyde coming from the West, and retourning from
the East.

This letter has been edited and discussed in (Shirley 1983, 432). The letter shows that Samuel Turner was responsible for introducing Harriot to the king's physician, Theodore Turquet de Mayerne, who was Harriot's doctor for the latter part of his life. The letter must have been written after the death of Harriot's previous physician, Peter Turner (May 1614), Samuel Turner's father. By the time this letter was written, Harriot already suffered for two or more years from the cancer of the nose that would eventually kill him.
Sr

These shall request you to forgive my absence
untill tomorrowe. Then I shall give you a
more particular accounte of my discourse with Mayerne.
in the meane time I shall lett you knowe
that he cannot possibly com to London, thoughe
he have many occasions to invite him to it
but he desires much to see you there:
but betweene this and tuesday he will
send you under his hand, the methode that
he wolde advise you in the cure: Tomorrow
I shall see you my selfe in the meane
time I remaine

Your assured frende
Sam Turner

To his very good
frende Mr
Hariot give
these
Sr

Though I have bene yet soe little a while att
new markett, that I have not any thing of
moment to ympart; yet I thinke it not amisse
to write a bare salutacions, and to let you know, that
in theise wearie iourneys I am oftentimes comforted
with the remembrance of your kind and paynes
bestowed on your loytering scholar, whose little
credit in the way of learning is allwaies under-
propped with the anme of soe worthy a Maister.
The Comet being spent, the talke of it still
runnes current here; The Kings Ma. before my
comming spake with one of Cambridge called
Olarentia, (a name able to beget belief of
some extraordinarie qualities) but what satis-
faction he gave, I cannot yet learne; here are
papers out of Spayne about it, yea and from
Roome, which I will endeavour to gett, and meane
that you shall partake of the newes as tyme . Cura ut valeas et me amos, who am ever
trulie and unfaynedly at your commande.
Tho: Aylesburie.

Draft of a letter, dated 5 April, 1616, to Harriot's doctor Theodore Turquet de Mayerne, to be sent via his pharmacist de Pleura. This letter, like the previous in the volume also to Turquet, has been freely translated in (Shirley 1983, 440-1), with extensive commentary on Harriot's disease and the remedies prescribed. Reference is made in the letter to Samuel Turner, son of Harriot's former doctor, who introduced Harriot to Mayerne (see fol. 442).

Cum his litteris (vir ornatissime) mitto virum nuncium ut mihi reportet quicquid a te ordinatum est pro meo usu. Nam dubito quin Dominus Turnerus interim tibi retulit omnia de statu ulceris ac etiam corporis. Summa est: Tubercula in imo septi quæ isto mense decidebant, quædam adhuc manent. Ita etiam manet adhuc quædam pars callosæ illius substantiæ prope summitatem et angulum quam bene notasti postremo visu. Sed tum putasti etiam Turnerus non esse vere callum. Cætere partes tamen habent statum. Bonum pus et Bona digestio et bonum pus accidit maxima ex parte. Aliquando plus, aliquando minus. Flante Austro vel occidentem versus cum pluviis, aliquando ulcus humidius est et sentio aliquam acrimoniam. Aliis temporibus nihil illius manet. Attamen non dubito quin quotidie aliquid emanat maligni quod impedit sanationem. De internæ partis male affectæ cura, a qua procedit ille humor malignus et de aversione, tuo doctissimo iuditio et ordinationi refero, cui
paratus sum libentissime, ut debeo, obtemperare. CONTINUE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Tui amantissimus
TH
Syon. April. 5. 1616.

div.head: Of Architecture SWL

p.s:
In building there is this rule præscribed by architectes
that the second story is in hight $ \frac{3}{4} $ of the first, & the third $ \frac{3}{4} $ of
the second.

The reason is: supposing the first to be Doricke with his
complements to the top of the corniss. The second must be Ionicke. And then understand
that the side of the base of the pedistall of the Ionicke be æquall to the diameter
of the Doricke base, because solid must be upon solid, & then the
rest of the Ionicke worke in proportion will make the sayd $ \frac{3}{4} $.

The third must be Corinthian. & the base of his pedistall
must be æquall to the diameter of the Ionick piller & the rest
with the complements will also bringe forth the sayd $ \frac{3}{4} $.

aut abominationem faciens et mendacium
nisi qui scripti sunt in libro vitæ
agni.

Out of Sr Walter Copes Apology
For the Earle of Salisbury

p.s:
Treasureship. He found dates there in the Exchequer of 3 or 400,000£, to the King, what
were separate what desperate no man knew. he sought
for better knowledge.
He caused his the K. Mannors to be surveyed.
The K. custodye landes anciently called the crowne landes
conserved in the pipe. The decayed revenues he
retained by the K. commission of Assertes.
He caused the K. woodes to be surveyed.
He raysed the K. revenues, out of the copyholders for
. Coppyholders for of inheritance. Mastes & commons
Casuall fines. extended lands surveyed.
He improved the customs, & advanced them from 86,000£
to 120,000£. & from 120,000£ to 135,000£ per anum.
He got money for the K. by from the dealers in Allome.
By his for the Baronets he hath brought into the K. coffers
80,000£.
By his bargayne for bringing water to London likely to bring
in great yearly reveneu to the K.
He was a patron of all Industry & manufactures, of there &
intentions. As for the of Allum, of Buffes, for fishing, Copper
& coperall copperall of Iron & steele, sault by the home, sault upon salt,
& men farmers & fiers for easy workmanship.

concerning his secretarys place &c.
& concerning the wardes &c.
I note nothing.

out of his answere to obiections
Queen Mary raysed cloth from 14d to a noble.
The Gascoigne wines from 3d to 4 markes.
Queen Elizab. raysed the sweet wines from 3s 6d to 40s the tonne.
And upon the currents for every 5 hundred 5s 6d.
He forebeare to impose upon & all natures incident to the poore & upon
all thinges concerning the ordinance, shippes, & defence of the realme
but imposed specially upon silkes, spices, lawnes, cambrickes, whale bones
& such like thinges rather of dilicacy then necessity, allowing free
liberty to transport without charge what was not vented here.

All I noted out of 10 leaves
in 40, the wh whole booke.

I borrowed the booke of
M. T. Buck. 1615. Ap.

* The seas & Merchant only
ever to before & therefore
the stat: 13 of Eliz. The
Marchant only hath power
passe & returne wihout
licence.

Towardes the latter end concerning Busses for fishing.
Anno 1611 it so far proceeded that after long consultation
we framed a body for the corporation consisting of a Governor
a deputy, a Treasurer, 24 consulls, 24 assistantes, a sercher,
a Guager, &c. with free liberty to all that would become adventurers.
We then agreed that the Government should be generall for matters
of order, particular for matter of adventure, having ever
at liberty to venture for itself.
We then agreed of lawes and ordinances for the generall company at
under & the particular companyes in the country that there might
& an æquall correspondence between them all.
We then agreed of 19 privileges that might give & comfort
to all the undertakers.
But when we came to the and that the end should have
crowned the work, when we came to the 17th privilege which
made it lawfull to carry our fish & returne commodityes from all
partes whatsoever notwithstanding all former privilege to the
contrary. All the companyes (especially the Adventurers) strongly
opposed it as if they should want commodityes for there & our return
we then offered them to make them parteners of our corpo-
ration which they refused.
We then demanded whether they wold make us in worse case
then the Hollanders who vented there great masse of fish in all
partes of the world, & made there returns home & better at
there pleasures. They answered that returnes into Holland did
them no hurt, Returnes into England might undo their great
trade of cloth.
And upon this uncharitable, uniust, & idle proposition, what should become
of our fish, before either Busses builded or nettes made or fish taken;
this great & noble worke of the Busses hath for these 2 yeares ben last
layd or asleep.
I call it uniust & uncharitable because agaynst the great Cha
& agaynst many other lawes of this realme. Agaynst the birthright
& freedom of every subject.
And against all leagues & treatyes of states.
As appeares in the treaty of Bruxelles the 24. Jan. 1515. between Cha
prince of Spayne & Henry 8. K. of England. And agaynst their second
treaty April. 11. 1520. betweene Charles the first then Emperor & our
& alos agaynst a third treaty 1529. and contrary to our privileges
granted by the hosue of Burgundy & by the Emperor of Moscovy &c.
In all which is allowed libertum commercium for the K. and all his subjects to come
& to go to buy to sell by land by sea in all clymes partes creekes &c. in
free liberall & ample manner as the very natives of his crowne kingdom
without exception or restraynt in favour of the Adventurers or any company
whatsoever. All lawes & treatyes ever ayming after liberty of trade. * above.
(No more I noted.)
